segments.text: up to it three times.
Sounds now as if it's a rehearsal for a movie.
Different story every time.
Okay.
That's the way historians do.
We change the story with regularity.
Start again with the Officer's Candidate School.
Explain why that you were in Officer's Candidate School from 40 to 42.
Well, it was because I was performing my normal military service, which is a one and a half year
period in Sweden, normally, during the war.
It became longer.
I was in for about three years.
And it seemed to me to make the best out of that time.

It would be most interesting to go to officer school, particularly if I was interested in the coast artillery, which combined the physical interest of ballistics and mathematics and also the contact with the sea.
And the first contact with the sea then that you experienced was really from your home and not from the military?
Oh yes, I grew up on the ocean, on the beautiful bay of the Baltic, which had very interesting natural features and therefore attracted my interest very much.
What degrees did you receive from the University of Stockholm prior to
the doctoral degree in science?
Well, the way you work it in Scandinavia, first you take your bachelor's degree.
And after that, work your way toward what corresponds more or less to a doctorate degree here, which is called licentiate degree.
And for a thesis in that connection, I worked on the problem I found fascinating.

namely studies of sedimentation in the past by using the type of deposit that occurs in the glacial strata around Scandinavia, where you can distinguish every single year and therefore establish a chronology and study processes on an absolute time basis.
How do you distinguish every year?
Does it fall in layers like, you mean like a tree reversed?

Exactly like tree rings, essentially, because in spring you get the flood, the melting, and that gives rise to a specific type of more coarse grain deposit, and in winter and fall and winter, things slow down and the character of the sediment, chemical character of sediment is different.
So therefore you get the kind of tree ring-like effect, and you can

measure the thicknesses of these rings, and therefore seek to reconstruct exactly the different hydrologic conditions and metrologic conditions during each year, and also use this sequence as a timekeeper and measure things on an absolute time basis.
Is that what began the Scandinavian's interest in deep sea drilling?
I wouldn't say so.
So the deposits of this kind were formed around the polar ice that covered Scandinavia during several ice ages.
And it's the basis for establishing the whole chronology for the ice ages.
And it gave me an interest, or it was an exponent of my interest,
putting geological phenomena on an absolute quantitative basis.
And with that background, it then became very interesting to go to the deep sea, where one knew that the sedimentation was much, much smaller.
Instead of having a fraction of an inch for each year, the same thickness of sediment corresponded to many thousand years.
So you have the chance to extend much, much further back in time.
That's what fascinated me first with deep sea geology.
Now, when was your first expedition that began to explore the sea in these terms, in terms of deep sea drilling?
The first expeditions with that specific aim in mind were a series of
of preliminary test expeditions in the North Sea and Skagerrak that were initiated by the, taken by the Oceanographic Institute in Gteborg.
And I was lucky enough to participate in these and also in the final shakedown cruise to the Mediterranean.
preceding the culmination of these efforts in the form of the Swedish deep-sea expedition with the Albatross, 1947 to 1948.
So the first major effort preceding that was then the Skagerrak expedition to the Mediterranean, called the Skagerrak expedition because the ship's name was Skagerrak in this case, in 1946.
And then you were on the Albatross in 1948.
47 to 48, 15 months.
And then when you come back from the Albatross, then you work with the Swedish National Research Council in compiling your data?

Well, the National Research Council provided essentially the fellowship support and research grant for the working up of the material collected from the East Pacific during the Albatross expedition, which
I had been given the opportunity to use as a basis for my doctoral science thesis work.
And when did you first make contact with Americans in terms of oceanographic work?
It's hard to pinpoint the first time.
It must have been in connection
probably with the Skagerrak expedition, the preliminaries leading to the Albatross expedition.
I developed correspondence with many people in this country who were interested in similar problems, particularly the people at Woods Hall and Lamont Geological Observatory, Morris Ewing there.
several of the geologists in the country that were not necessarily associated with oceanography, but who were fascinated by these new possibilities.
And finally, and foremost, with the staff here at Scripps Institutional Oceanography, Roger Revelle, and some of the other people working here.
How did you manage to come to Scripps?
It was a natural choice for what I thought would be a
maybe half a year or a year post-doctoral work.
After spending four years of working up the material from the East Pacific, which showed some very interesting previously unknown features, it was fascinating enough.
So I wanted to at least devote a few more years to that problem.
And the logical place, the center in the world for Pacific
oceanographic studies was scripts, so that was an obvious choice.
And whom did you contact here?
One of the things that I found most inspiring in my thesis work was the thesis by Roger Revelle that had just then come out, quite strongly delayed again by the war.
It worked on material collected by the American Carnegie expedition much earlier.
But the material had not been worked up until he started investigating it.
And his monograph on this is a very impressive piece of work, plus the fact that he was the man who inspired and controlled this place at the time made me write to him.
And?
Well, I didn't hear anything for, must have been half a year.
I think I wrote him in Christmas, around Christmas time, 1940, 1951.
I spent the Christmas together with my wife's family in Copenhagen and at the Bohr Institute.
And Niels Bohr.
further encouraged me to take that step and to go for a postdoctoral period here.
He'd also heard about Scripps.
But sometime in May the following year, I got a letter from a man whom I didn't know at that time, but who since then has become a great friend of mine, John D. Isaacs.
And he explained to me in his letter, which was rather brief, that
That day, a whole pile of papers had fallen down from the director's desk.
And he was assistant to the director.
And when he picked up the papers, he found my letter among them.
And he felt he should answer some of the letters.
And he picked mine.
And his answer was, yes, why don't you come?
That was all.
I took that as an expression of the informality and directness of approach to science in the United States.
and embarked on the trip over.
Now, obviously you stayed here now.
Why the change from research to professor?
Was there any...?
At the time when I came here, Scripps Institutional Oceanography was a kind of exceptional institution in the university and had very few faculty positions.
They were
very difficult to get.

So Roger Revelle, who wanted to attract new scientists to the institution at a much higher rate than he could possibly get faculty positions for, used research staff positions for this purpose, and he offered such a position to me.
And then you worked on research, and then from there you moved on into teaching when?
Well, actually, there's no border between teaching and research in Scripps.
I was teaching then insofar as we had contact with students around here.
And I'm doing as much research after the change in title that you referred to, which didn't mean anything much in fact, just more of an administrative
arrangement that you would call professor instead of research?
Well, what I'm interested in is what appears to be biogeochemistry.
Well, that thing stemmed from partly the fact that in much of my work in the ocean settlements, I had become to depend much on the record provided by
the fossils of organisms.
They provided a very rich, both chemical and paleontological evidence to tell you where you were and what had happened in the past.
That is a characteristic feature of the EBC settlements, that they have a large proportion of tiny skeletons of microscopic animals and plants.
So part of my geochemical work involved biological questions
And when Roger Revelle kindly wanted to arrange for a professorship for me, he had to look for the best strategic way of doing it.
And he had just succeeded in obtaining a million dollar grant from the Rockefeller Foundation for the rejuvenation of biology in script.
And here he saw me as a biologist suddenly.
And in order to
to be able to incorporate this work I was doing in the general scheme of things.
He therefore called the professorship of biogeochemistry.
Well, when one reads the way you've approached work, it seems as if you begin as a generalist and then you become a specialist in
And then you broaden out to be a journalist again.
Is that a fair description of your career?
I'm afraid that's the case, yes.
Do you prefer to be a journalist?
Is that the way you conceive of the role of a scientist?
I think a scientist must renew himself all the time.
And to renew yourself, you have to approach problems, new problems, and see problems in a different perspective.
You must learn something about other branches of science.
And that has a great danger that you spread yourself too thin.
But the interesting thing is to learn new things.
And I'm afraid if you get too specialized, then you might very well become an authority, but life will eventually become boring.
Well, is oceanography especially suited to the sort of journalist, specialist, journalist approach as an academic discipline?
Yes.

is, and I would say earth sciences in general, because there's no barrier between oceanography, earth sciences in general, and from earth sciences in general, there's no barrier between that and space science, and the question of the laws that rule our universe or our solar system.
These diffused borders make a very wide field, but it also makes it necessary to learn a large number of things.
Let me offer an explanation before I ask the question.
Many American oceanographers, if that's fair to say, began as meteorologists and moved into oceanography through submarine warfare training
in one way or through meteorological work in the Air Force, the other.
Who do you think are specifically?
I'm thinking of people like Spellhouse, for example, who is only an American in terms of being naturalized, and those people who trained with the Air Force with him.
And the other way, I'm thinking about people who moved out of oceanography and into space like yourself.
Does there seem to be a blending together of atmosphere, space, and the ocean?
That's certainly true, particularly for the people who deal with...

The physics of the ocean, the motion of ocean currents, there is no particular principle difference between the motion of the fluid that forms atmosphere and the motion of the fluid that forms the ocean.
And if you can treat one, you have the tools for treating the other.
So there's often a blend of atmospheric and
and oceanic sciences among these people.
Ross Bue, Walter Munk, John Isaacs, you see many others.
Now, is this what led you to turn your attention towards space?
What I'm trying to find out is what specifically led you from the oceans to space.
Oh, I'd always been interested in that.
And again, it came much from the work of particularly

One of my ancestors, back in the 1870s, was an Arctic explorer, but also very interested in the question of interaction of the Earth with space, the question of how the Earth had formed, the dust that it had accreted from, and what meteorites could tell us about the origin of the solar system.
And I was always fascinated by his work.
In the deep sea sediments, you also find traces of the influx of cosmic materials onto the Earth in the form of fine cosmic dust that is not so diluted in the deep sea as it is on land.
And the work with that then led me on still further into these questions that I already earlier had been interested in.
And particularly the presence here, we succeeded in attracting to Scripps
one of the great authorities in this field named Professor Harold Urey.
And everybody around Harold Urey becomes enthusiastic by what he's doing.
That further catalyzed my interest in this field.
Okay.
And so you seem to think it was natural then to, if I may coin a word, to sort of relate the sciences of the galaxy with the sciences of the ocean?
Or I would say the science of the solar system with that of the ocean.
The galaxy, as such, is a step I haven't taken yet.
Okay.
Then what is the Space Research Laboratory?
Because that implies galaxy to be.
Well, you can divide space into near space.
Okay.
And the solar system, which is essentially our bound system,
And then, as you say, the galaxy, which is a much larger concept, much more enormous.

And I've never been, or I've limited myself so far to the questions of our solar system, particularly because with the techniques that I'm using and the material that I'm using, one has access essentially by observation only to the, or mostly to the solar system.
But I'm sorry, what's your question?
What is the Space Research Laboratory?
Oh.
The Space Research Laboratory, again, was a convenience of the time.
There were several people at the time here on campus.
The campus was growing now under Roger Revelle's direction.
And we started to accumulate on purpose many physicists and chemists who were interested in
Not only the ocean, but the Earth as a whole and the solar system and the universe.
People like Harold Dury first, Professor James Arnold, the Burbidges, Professor Jeffrey and Margaret Burbidge.
And after a while, Professor McIlwain, for example, has done lots of work on the Van Allen belts and the radiation belts around the Earth.
And it became a practical...

administrative matter to try to pull all these things, all these people together into some kind of organization that was very loose and perhaps more consisted in a work than the Space Research Institute, which then served as an organization to deal with the outside world, particularly the sponsoring agency that was NASA.
What were your actions as director?
That's what I would like to find out.
What kind of direction did you try to give to the Space Institute?
Practically nothing.
That was essentially...
The idea was to...
I mean, at that time, scientists were very individualistic, and there was no great attempt to force everybody to do the same thing.
So the idea was that only one of Herb York, who was chancellor at the time,
to create an umbrella for all of these people.

And what I had to do was a minimum of integration of results to present them to the space agency to convince them that our campus was a worthy recipient of further funding and particularly student support.
What is the Institute for the Study of Matter?
Well, that is yet another interesting creation in the early days of the expanded campus here.
Due to the arrival of the great solid state physicist, Professor Bernd Matthias, who is
one of the foremost pioneers in the field, particularly of material science in general, and particularly superconductivity.
And he was one of our great catches.
And again, he's a very inspiring and brilliant man who enthusiasmates everybody around him.
And he established, and then
again for the purpose of generating an umbrella for all activists in the field, an institute called the Institute for the Study of Matter.
And I felt that I would like to branch a little into that fundamental field to learn more about the atomic molecular structure of the solids that I depended on in my work.
joined in his effort in those early days.
Okay, now, your publications have concentrated on the geology, chemistry, and physics of outer space, interspersed with occasional articles on marine geochemistry, if I understand it correctly.
Would you agree with that?
And also material science.
And materials.
Okay, right.
I would agree with that, certainly.
Now,
Is space then a key to oceans for you or is space by itself for you in terms of research?

I see it all as an interrelated system and the oceans are a very interesting special phenomenon generated on some of the planets due to the separation from the primordial matter of water on the surface of the planet and I like
to understand the ocean partly as it exists today and the processes it shows today, partly as a recorder of the most immediate past history of the Earth.
That means the last something like 100 million years, the very most recent pages in the history of the Earth.
But space science has opened up for us
questions that refer to the very earliest history of the Earth that are no longer recorded in any existing settlements because they've been wiped out.
And we can learn from what we see on other planets and in material that has not yet formed any planets.
From that we can learn where the ocean originally came from and how it originally formed.
Okay, good.
What was the American Chemical Society
PRF award presented in honor of in 1961?

Oh, I guess it must have been in response or some recognition of the work that started with the work on the Deep Sea Expedition and continued its scripts afterward, trying to clear up some of the questions of the metabolism, of the chemical metabolism of the ocean.
and the relationship between the ocean sediments or the use of the ocean sediments as a record of the past history of the Earth.
